message.content:
By the quadratic formula, we obtain that the solution to $ax^2+20x+c=0$ is
$$x=\frac{-20\pm\sqrt{20^2-4ac}}{2a} = \frac{-20\pm 20\sqrt{1-\frac{c}{5a}}}{2a} = \frac{-10\pm\sqrt{4(1-\frac{c}{5a})}}{a}$$Since the quadratic has only one solution, the discriminant must be equal to 0. Thus
$$4\left(1-\frac{c}{5a}\right) = 0 \Rightarrow a=\frac{c}{5}$$We can then substitute this into $a+c = 29$ to obtain the system of equations
\begin{align*} a+c &= 29\\ a &= \frac{c}{5} \end{align*}Solving gives
\begin{align*} a &= \frac{25}{6}\\ c &= \frac{145}{6} \end{align*}Therefore, $(a,c)=\boxed{\left(\frac{25}{6}, \frac{145}{6}\right)}$.
